III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Bethany Christian Services TLC is a single-story residential facility with a
basement. When you enter through the front door, there is a storage closet to the
right, two bathrooms to the left, and another small closet with no door on the left.
The door for the stairs leading to the basement as well as the supervisor's office
are also on the left. Once you turn the corner to the right, the first door on the left
is a staff office area and the second door on the left is the laundry room. There is
a small hallway on the left, which leads to the therapy office, and a back egress
door leading to the deck with stairs leading down to the gravel/grass area. Back in
the main area of the facility, there is an open concept design for the kitchen,
dining room, living room, and a cubicle area for staff. There are doors leading to
seven bedrooms (2 singles, 2 doubles, 3 triples), as well as three bathrooms.
There is also a door leading to a prayer/private room for youth meditation, and a
second egress door leading outside to the front of the facility. Across from the
kitchen, there is a hallway with storage closet with cleaning items, and two
pantries. This hallway leads back towards the main front door entrance.
The basement has a main living area, a game room with two closets (containing
games, school activities/supplies, etc.), an egress door leading outside, and an
office for the case management staff. There are cameras throughout the facility
which record video but not sound.
An Environmental Health Inspection completed on 12/5/24 received an "A-
Rating".

B. Program Description
Bethany Christian Services TLC (Transitional Living Center) program is a
specialized community-based residential licensed home equipped to house single
unaccompanied refugee minors. The home specialized is both mental health
treatment as well as intensive independent living skills preparation, in order to
prepare program recipients to be successful members of the community upon
discharge. The program provides an intensive, structured, and routine-driven
setting that incorporates supportive staff members, therapists, community
supporters, and volunteers.
Youth residing in the program are males ages 15-17 who are unaccompanied
minors new to the United States. The ratio of youth to staff is 1:8 during awake
hours, and 1:16 during sleeping hours. Many of the youth offer a unique challenge
for treatment due to their extensive history of abuse, neglect, or abandonment,
and subsequent trauma history during travel to the U.S. The program serves
youth who have been screened eligible for community-based living after being
stepped down from shelters as well as secure and staff-secure facilities, after
careful screening. Youth at TLC can either be UC UAMs or URMs. There are 8
designated beds for UC UAMs, and 7 for URMs. Both statuses have the same
responsibilities and are held to the same standard.
TLC uses the Personalized Independence Education (PIE) model to highlight the
importance of independence and freedom, along with the responsibilities that
come with it. Each level, or "PIE slice" focuses on an area necessary to live
independently. Once the youth master’s the PIE slice, they move onto the next,
until the PIE is completed, and they graduate from the program. The 10 PIE slices
include orientation, US culture, personal health, sexual education, legal, education
& employment, money management, housing, transition independence, and
health & wellness.
TLC's treatment philosophy follows the Sanctuary Model of Care, which ensures
treatment is trauma responsive. The facility follows Crisis Prevention Institute
(CPI) for de-escalation as well as physical intervention. This model was approved
by the DCWL Director on 1/22/25.
3

TLC has an intensive therapeutic and educationally based skills training program
to meet the youth's individual needs and utilize the strengths of the youth served.
Youth are offered a variety of structured activities, groups, classes, and other
programming. These services include cultural orientation group, intensive case-
management services, 24/7 crisis intervention, advanced independent living skills
training, public school education, English as a second language classes, Spanish
literacy classes, tutoring/study time sessions, mentoring services, dialectical
behavioral group therapy, recreation/activity therapy, individual therapy by on-site
program therapist, community and in-home activities, and interpretation services.
It is anticipated youth in the program stay at TLC until they're ready for
independent living, or another appropriate placement. This typically takes
approximately 9 months but could be shorter or longer depending on the youth's
individualized needs as well as available placement resources. Upon intake, each
youth is assigned a case manager, who meets with the youth within 24 hours after
intake, and a minimum of weekly thereafter. Within 30 days of intake, all youth are
assessed to determine what types of behavioral interventions are required, and a
detailed behavioral plan is put into place to ensure a successful transition into the
home, school, and community.
